title: An Author of No Imagination... whose treatment of tragic events is quite bizarre
content: The book attempts to document the life of an extraordinary woman, Virginia Hall, one of America's pioneering covert operatives in occupied France during WWII. How the author could take such a riveting and compelling topic and hammer the life out of it is beyond me. The book is written in the style of an academic thesis mashed up with a neverending newspaper article. There are perhaps one billion footnotes, although I might be exaggerating somewhat. The author evidently had access to an extraordinary trove of documentation and correspondence from the key players in the story, but the reader never gains any insight into what things must have been like for any of the participants. In fact, no attempt was made to gain any such perspective. Many tiny, obscure details are documented, with absolutely no regard for the overall meandering flow of the narrative. People and places are introduced, never to be heard from again. The elements of the story are presented with the emotional range of a recipe for a cake. Things like... They hiked into this valley. Here's the name of the valley. Here's the name of the stream they crossed. Here's the name of the road. Then they killed these Germans. Then they found a safe house. Then they went to sleep because they were tired. Then they woke up and dodged the other Germans looking for them. Then they learned their friends had been horribly tortured for weeks and had their faces smashed in. Then these other French people were rounded up and shot through the head for talking to Hall. Then Hall felt sad. Then Hall learned to make cheese, but the cheese wasn't very good cheese. Frankly, the tone was bizarre and almost sociopathic. The horrors of war were brushed over with the indifference one might have for an insignificant sporting event. Based on the author's odd tone, she evidently views the war as a game in which Hall performed quite well. The scores were documented, and a play-by-play account was given, but this reader felt like the recipient of an emotionless data dump.

title: Verified Purchase
content: When visiting the Washington, DC Spy museum, I read and saw a few snippets about Virginia Hall.  She was an amazing woman.  On the current CIA campus, she is the only woman to have a building named after her.  Virginia’s life was definitely a 5/5, but felt Purnell up-played this woman’s heroics while down-playing her faults and too often the author interpreted what she thought Virginia Hall was feeling rather than sticking to the facts.  Clearly an amazing amount of research went into this novel filled with numerous names and locations, in which I did sometimes get bogged down.  Am glad to see that a movie has been scheduled to be made about Hall’s extraordinaire life starring Daisy Ridley and I look forward to seeing how the director edits the material.  Virginia was born into a well-to-do family, but the money was lost in 1929 and she floundered as well.  While traveling in France, she fell in love with the country.  Since the USA only wanted her for her typing or ambulance skills, the British gratefully took her on as a spy against the Germans in WWII, this despite her missing foot.  She had a great capacity for disguise and inventiveness, charm to gather dedicated people to help her, and a strong ability to keep secrets.  I found it surprising that one of her greatest challenges was to keep the French from bickering with each other.  I would rate the book a 4.

title: An American socialite who becomes a hero in Britain, The US AND France
content: Sonia Purnell has meticulously researched historical records and recently declassified documents to render a fascinating biography of Virginia Hall that reads like a spy novel except that it's "real". Virginia Hall was a truly remarkable person whose contributions to the French resistance during WWII were unsurpassed and, unfortunately unappreciated because of her sex. Because of her knowledge gained from living in France and driving an ambulance after the Fall of Paris, she secured a position with the covert Special Operations Executive (SOE) branch of British MI6. Operating in Vichy France, she proved herself adept at setting up safe houses and recruiting resistance allies organized as networks of cells. Virginia was hampered in her efforts by being made subordinate to male agents less competent than she, and sometimes incompetent. The Gestapo and SS certainly recognized her competence and made her the "Most Wanted" spy in France. After making a harrowing escape thought southern France over the Pyrenees to Spain, she rejoined the OSE in England. The OSE would not let her return to France because her identity was compromised. Virginia learned to be a wireless operator and was recruited by the Wild Bill Donovan's OSS. This allowed her to pursue her dream of being a covert field agent and contributing to the resistance effort in freeing France from German occupation. That she could accomplish so much (in spite of her subordinate status as a woman with a disability - Read the book) is a testament to her integrity, perseverance, and commitment. The author has incorporated personal insights gained through interviews with Virginia's niece. I highly recommend this book.

title: Verified Purchase
content: Virginia Hall was a socialite who from an early age loved adventure, instilled by her beloved father.  Her mother wanted her to marry into high society but Virginia gravitated to France where she fell in love with the country. When the Nazis were taking over France she drove ambulances to save people despite great danger. She wanted to continue helping France in the formal diplomatic service but ended up being rejected at every turn because of her gender and her wooden leg. As the war darkened four  years before the Normandy landing, she was "discovered" by a British officer when she was driving ambulances through great danger. He believed in her extraordinary stamina, courage, and burning dedication to ridding France of the Nazis. Virginia was  the first person to work for the British Secret Service to start building a resistance force in France.  The story of how she recruited many hundreds of resisters and managed the disruption of countless Nazi war resources  is riveting. She is responsible for keeping the French Resistance alive despite harrowing events, loss of many heroic recruits, her own near death and starvation, and unbelievable physical pain as she walked hundreds of miles including over the Pyrenees Mountains. The descriptions of Nazi terror are a wake up call to the danger of authoritarianism gone wild. If you thought you knew what the word "resistance" means, you will think differently about it after you read this book.

title: A Woman Of No Importance - Who Did Not Believe It Was True
content: This was a fascinating book to read. Virginia Hall's strong independent character, and ability to defy the naysayers to accomplish the impossible were her forte. She overcame repeated setbacks to her career goals because women in those days of the 1930s and into the war years of WWII were not supposed to do those things she desired to do...and did do. Especially when she became an amputee in her early career. As an amputee she went behind enemy lines in France two times to lead and inspire the French Resistance against the Nazi occupation. She served brilliantly with both the British Special Operations Executive (SOE), and the US OSS. She was the first woman awarded the Distinguished Service Cross the second highest US award for valor in combat. After the war the discrimination against her moving up the ladder at the CIA was still in effect. But her strong will & determination coupled with her feisty demeanor finally ended her career at the CIA. Lastly, this book reveals to the reader what "TOTAL WAR" really looks like where the allies did what it took to win. This type of determination is now in short supply in the US and other western democracies because being bad to the bad guys ain't nice no more..
